Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: The role of Maternal Hormones in Programming Offspring Aggression
Award.AbstractNarration:
A mother's hormonal response to her current environment can cause permanent changes in her developing offspring, potentially determining whether those offspring live or die in their future environment. Females breeding in more competitive environments tend to transfer more testosterone to their offspring prenatally, which permanently makes offspring more aggressive. This maternal effect may help offspring adapt to competitive environments, yet it is still unclear how maternally derived testosterone permanently impacts offspring behavior. Without knowing how it happens, it is difficult to characterize the heritability of this maternal effect and how it fits into larger evolutionary frameworks. This research is among the first to test if molecular mechanisms, such as changes in gene expression and control, mediate the effects of maternal testosterone on offspring aggression using birds, in which this maternal effect is best studied. This research will take a novel approach by exploring differences in aggression-related genes from several brain pathways. The results of this research will help clarify what contributes to long-lasting variation in aggressive behaviors and why differences in animal behaviors exist. The researchers will also train undergraduate students in laboratory methods and bioinformatics. Additionally, this research has lent itself to a citizen science project with songbird breeders throughout the United States to explore factors influencing avian reproduction.

Specifically, the researchers will experimentally determine if an epigenetic mechanism (i.e., DNA methylation) underlies the programming of offspring aggression by maternal hormones in songbirds. Birds are excellent models for maternal effects because their young develop externally in eggs and females allocate substantial amounts of testosterone to their egg yolks. The researchers will inject zebra finch eggs with a control vehicle or testosterone and measure aggressive and competitive behaviors (i.e., growth rate and begging rate) in the resulting offspring. In a subset of these offspring, the researchers will test for evidence of epigenetic programming. Aggressive behaviors are initiated across many interacting genes (i.e., steroid receptors, histamine, dopamine, somatostatin, arginine vasotocin, etc.). Thus, the researchers will use RNA-seq and methyl-seq analyses to explore genome-wide differences in mRNA expression and site-specific methylation patterns of aggression-related genes in two socially-relevant brain regions, the telencephalon and diencephalon. This research will greatly expand our knowledge of how different gene networks interact across brain regions to express aggression and will provide one of the first avian DNA methylomes. All data generated in this project will be archived in appropriate electronic repositories.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We know that a mother’s hormonal response to changes in her environment can create long-lasting variation in her offspring’s traits, like metabolism, immune function, and behaviors. However, it is still unclear how females are able to exert this effect. One of the best studied examples of this maternal effect is the observation that females breeding in more competitive environments, which require her to be more aggressive, transfer more steroid hormones (i.e., testosterone) to her developing offspring. Offspring exposed to higher levels of testosterone prenatally then display more aggressive behaviors well into adulthood. The goal of this project was to determine how exposure to high prenatal testosterone is able to alter offspring behaviors long term. We used a well-established songbird model (the zebra finch) and exposed offspring to testosterone or a control during development. We found that the offspring that had been exposed to experimentally elevated testosterone were more aggressive as adults, in addition to several other changes, like faster juvenile growth and greater competitive behaviors in the nest while soliciting parents for food. The Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant then allowed us to examine genome-wide changes in gene expression and DNA methylation (i.e., an epigenetic effect that modifies gene expression without changing DNA) in the brain to better elucidate how testosterone affected these traits. We found that hundreds of genes were differentially expressed in a sex-specific manner in behaviorally relevant brain regions (i.e., amygdala and hypothalamus). Additionally, several hypothalamic genes associated with aggression-related pathways, such as nitric oxide and serotonin, were directly related to aggressive behaviors in males. We also found several differentially methylated regions that strongly suggest exposure to prenatal testosterone can permanently affect behaviors by modifying gene expression patterns. This project has greatly increased our understanding of the mechanisms that mediate maternal effects, which helps clarify how they fit into larger ecological and evolutionary frameworks. More specifically, this study helped determined what contributes to long-lasting variation in aggressive behaviors.

 

This project enabled the co-PI to get extensive research experience learning new lab and computational techniques (e.g., how to handle large data sets), which was facilitated through collaborations with faculty in other departments and universities. These new collaborative relationships, along with the opportunities to present at professional meetings that this project afforded, led to the co-PI’s retention in the field after receiving a PhD. Since then, the co-PI has presented the results of this project at numerous guest lectures and university seminars to not only spread the knowledge gained through the project but also to excite and encourage undergraduate students to pursue a STEM career. The results from this project also have the potential to more broadly impact the field of medicine. While maternal effects can adaptively prepare offspring for the environment they are about to enter, they can also maladaptively shape offspring, causing long-term disorders, if the maternal environment is not representative of the offspring’s environment. Therefore, by clarifying which genes are susceptible to hormone exposure during prenatal development, this project will help future work focused on pharmacological interventions for behavioral disorders arising from prenatal hormone exposure.
